title: Virtuelle Akademie
text:
Die Freude am Lernen steht bei uns an erster Stelle. Aber wie gelingt ein Lernprozess im heutigen Hochschulumfeld? Wir glauben, dass exzellente Lehre aus der richtigen Mischung von didaktischer Kompetenz und digitalen Skills entsteht. Damit der Zauber funktioniert, unterst√ºtzen wir Lehrpersonen mit einem breiten evidenzbasierten Angebot, vom massgeschneiderten Einzel-Coaching √ºber kompakte Weiterbildungen bis hin zum CAS-Studiengang.
In unserer Arbeit setzen wir stets auf eine offene und wertsch√§tzende Kommunikation. Unser Fokus liegt auf der Praxis: Wir behandeln echte Problemstellungen aus dem Lehralltag und orientieren uns nicht an kurzfristigen Trends. Damit leisten wir einen Beitrag zu einer nachhaltigen Transformation in der Bildung und einem sorgf√§ltigen Umgang mit digitalen Werkzeugen.

title: About
text: Ich bin an der Hochschulbibliothek der BFH verantwortlich f√ºr die Koordination der IK-Angebote. Wir und unsere Kolleg*innen an der Ausleihe haben vermehrt mit Studierenden zu tun, die eine ¬´Recherche¬ª mit ChatGPT durchf√ºhren oder auf andere Art damit arbeiten. Ich denke, f√ºr die Informationswissenschaft wird die KI einiges an Ver√§nderungen mit sich bringen. Noch gibt es aber kaum Informationsanl√§sse f√ºr unsere Branche. K√∂nntest du dir vorstellen, f√ºr unser Team IK eine Einf√ºhrung ins Thema zu geben und Vor- und Nachteile aufzuzeigen?

title: About
text:
Fragensammlung

Wie funktioniert ChatGPT genau? Welche anderen relevanten KI-Tools sollte man kennen?


Didaktik/Methodik:

N√ºtzliche Unterst√ºtzung im Unterricht durch ChatGPT (zB Kahoot und Pr√§sentationen erstellen) ‚Äì kennst du Anleitungen, gute Vorgehensweisen?
Abschlussarbeiten und ChatGPT
Plagiate erkennen



Fragen aus dem Berufsfeld Information und Dokumentation:

Technische Einsatzm√∂glichkeiten von ChatGPT bei der Recherche oder in Discovery-Tools (Recherchetechnologien) in Zukunft
ChatGPT nutzen, um eine Recherche vorzubereiten? Thema einkreisen, Begriffe sammeln etc.
Literaturhinweise, die ChatGPT ausspielt
Neue Aufgabe f√ºr I&D-Institutionen: KI-generiertes Wissen einordnen?
Urheberrecht: Wem geh√∂rt ein KI-Text?



Risiken

Risiken von ChatGPT: fachliche Unkorrektheit, Unwahrheit
Was k√∂nnen wir den Studierenden in unseren Workshops mitgeben?
Ethisch bedenkliche Hintergr√ºnde von ChatGPT: https://www.srf.ch/radio-srf-1/kuenstliche-intelligenz-traumatisiert-weil-sie-den-chat-roboter-trainieren-mussten

title: About
text:
Beispiel

wir hatten mehrfach Studierende in den Bibliotheken, die mit ChatGPT ¬´Literaturrecherchen¬ª machten und dann mit langen Listen von Referenzen nicht existierender B√ºcher und Artikel daher kamen üòä einige Kolleginnen an der Ausleihe haben dann, nat√ºrlich vergeblich, danach gesucht. Vielleicht kannst du etwas dazu sagen, wie solche falschen bibliographischen Angaben entstehen.

title: GPT is Not An Oracle
text:
mathematische Basiskompetenzen im Kindergartenalter

Du bist eine Fachperson im Bereich der Entwicklungspsychologie. Du bist Experte f√ºr mathematische Basiskompetenzen im Kindergartenalter. Ich schreibe eine Masterarbeit und du hilfst mir bei den Formulierungen. Ich schreibe eine wissenschaftliche Arbeit √ºber das Thema ‚ÄúErfassung mathematischer Basiskompetenzen‚Äù

Der MBK 0 (Test mathematischer Basiskompetenzen im Kindergartenalter) von Krajewski (2018) ist ein Einzeltest f√ºr Kinder im Alter von 3.6 bis 7 Jahren. Diesem Test liegt das Entwicklungsmodell der Zahl-Gr√∂ssen-Verkn√ºpfung (Krajewski, 2008) zugrunde (vgl. Abschnitt 4.2.1). Der MBK 0 ist ein Test zur Erfassung der mathematischen Basiskompetenzen

title: GPT is Not An Oracle
text:
As Large Language Models (LLMs) become increasingly human-like in their performance, it is important to develop effective ways to describe their behaviour using high-level concepts, without falling into the trap of anthropomorphism.
In this workshop, we will investigate how LLMs are trained, how they produce text, and what they are capable of. Importantly, we will address what LLMs are not capable of, and how to use them correctly. We will also discuss similarities and differences between LLMs and human thought processes.
Specifically, we will address the way that people seem to want to use ChatGPT as an oracle, whose goal is to provide truthful statements. We will discuss why is not the case, and how to use LLMs correctly.

title: Prompt Design
text:
Doc OpenAI‚Äôs GPT (generative pre-trained transformer) models have been trained to understand natural language and code. GPTs provide text outputs in response to their inputs. The inputs to GPTs are also referred to as ‚Äúprompts‚Äù. Designing a prompt is essentially how you ‚Äúprogram‚Äù a GPT model, usually by providing instructions or some examples of how to successfully complete a task.
Using GPTs, you can build applications to:
Draft documents
Write computer code
Answer questions about a knowledge base
Analyze texts
Create conversational agents
Give software a natural language interface
Tutor in a range of subjects
Translate languages
Simulate characters for games
and much more
To use a GPT model via the OpenAI API, you‚Äôll send a request containing the inputs and your API key, and receive a response containing the model‚Äôs output. Our latest models, gpt-4 and gpt-3.5-turbo, are accessed through the chat completions API endpoint. Currently, only the older legacy models are available via the completions API endpoint.

title: Prompt Design
text:
Doc OpenAI‚Äôs GPT (generative pre-trained transformer) models have been trained to understand natural language and code. GPTs provide text outputs in response to their inputs. The inputs to GPTs are also referred to as ‚Äúprompts‚Äù. Designing a prompt is essentially how you ‚Äúprogram‚Äù a GPT model, usually by providing instructions or some examples of how to successfully complete a task.
Using GPTs, you can build applications to:
Draft documents
Write computer code
Answer questions about a knowledge base
Analyze texts
Create conversational agents
Give software a natural language interface
Tutor in a range of subjects
Translate languages
Simulate characters for games
and much more
To use a GPT model via the OpenAI API, you‚Äôll send a request containing the inputs and your API key, and receive a response containing the model‚Äôs output. Our latest models, gpt-4 and gpt-3.5-turbo, are accessed through the chat completions API endpoint. Currently, only the older legacy models are available via the completions API endpoint.

title: Prompt Design
text:
GPT best practices
This guide shares strategies and tactics for getting better results from GPTs. The methods described here can sometimes be deployed in combination for greater effect. We encourage experimentation to find the methods that work best for you.
Some of the examples demonstrated here currently work only with our most capable model, gpt-4. If you don‚Äôt yet have access to gpt-4 consider joining the waitlist. In general, if you find that a GPT model fails at a task and a more capable model is available, it‚Äôs often worth trying again with the more capable model. Six strategies for getting better results Write clear instructions
GPTs can‚Äôt read your mind. If outputs are too long, ask for brief replies. If outputs are too simple, ask for expert-level writing. If you dislike the format, demonstrate the format you‚Äôd like to see. The less GPTs have to guess at what you want, the more likely you‚Äôll get it.

Tactics:
Include details in your query to get more relevant answers
Ask the model to adopt a persona
Use delimiters to clearly indicate distinct parts of the input
Specify the steps required to complete a task
Provide examples
Specify the desired length of the output

title: Prompt Design
text:
Provide reference text
GPTs can confidently invent fake answers, especially when asked about esoteric topics or for citations and URLs. In the same way that a sheet of notes can help a student do better on a test, providing reference text to GPTs can help in answering with fewer fabrications.

Tactics:
Instruct the model to answer using a reference text
Instruct the model to answer with citations from a reference text

title: Prompt Design
text: Strategy: Give GPTs time to ‚Äúthink‚Äù

title: The title of the presentation
text:
Naive
Q: A juggler has 16 balls. Half of the balls are golf balls and half of the golf balls are blue. How many blue golf balls are there?
A:
There are 8 blue golf balls.

title: The title of the presentation
text:
Let‚Äôs think step by step

Q: A juggler has 16 balls. Half of the balls are golf balls and half of the golf balls are blue. How many blue golf balls are there? A: Let‚Äôs think step by step.

There are 16 balls in total. 
Half of the balls are golf balls. 
That means that there are 8 golf balls. 
Half of the golf balls are blue. 
That means that there are 4 blue golf balls.

title: GPT is Not An Oracle
text:
As Large Language Models (LLMs) become increasingly human-like in their performance, it is important to develop effective ways to describe their behaviour using high-level concepts, without falling into the trap of anthropomorphism.
In this workshop, we will investigate how LLMs are trained, how they produce text, and what they are capable of. Importantly, we will address what LLMs are not capable of, and how to use them correctly. We will also discuss similarities and differences between LLMs and human thought processes.
Specifically, we will address the way that people seem to want to use ChatGPT as an oracle, whose goal is to provide truthful statements. We will discuss why is not the case, and how to use LLMs correctly.

title: GPT is Not An Oracle
text:
Instructors

Andrew Ellis - Andrew is a data scientist at the Bern University of Applied Sciences. He has a background in cognitive science, and is fascinated by the intersection of language, cognition, and computation.

title: GPT is Not An Oracle
text:
Tutorial Content

0: Instructions. Some instructions on the tools used in the workshop. It would be handy to read this before the workshop starts!
1: What is ChatGPT and how does is work?. A brief introduction to the ChatGPT model, and how it works.
2: How do you use ChatGPT?. A discussion of what can do, and how to use it correctly.
3: Concepts for thinking about ChatGPT. A discussion of how to think about ChatGPT, and how it is similar and different to human thought.
